NewWords.WordPhrase: v. exchange (one thing) for another 交换
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I'll swap my orange for your apple.

NewWords.WordPhrase: mention or describe (sb. or sth.) as 将……称为
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The professor referred to him as a graduate student with a bright future.
e.g. We have brought in a good grain harvest for three years on end.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 个人用品，衣物；装备；齿轮
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. All our camping gear has been packed up.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. move from one place to another 迁移
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In winter, some birds migrate to find warmer weather.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. proof; a declaration by a witness 证明；证词
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A witness gave testimony that the accused was drunk.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. fill completely; soak 使充满；浸透
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The air was saturated with the perfume of the flowers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. select and set aside for a specific purpose 选定（或指定）……（作某种用途）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He designated Smith as his successor.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. force into less space 压缩
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He compressed his report into three pages.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. express grief or discontent 悲叹，抱怨
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Almost immediately he began to complain about the weather.

NewWords.WordPhrase: relevant(ly) 相关的（地），切中要害的（地）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. What he was saying is short and to the point.
e.g. Look over your exercises before handing them in.
e.g. There is no general agreement on a standard definition of intelligence.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a favorable position or factor, sth. good 优势，优点，好处
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Mary speaks good English, but she has an advantage because her mother is English.

NewWords.WordPhrase: sit comfortably; become quiet or calm; begin living a stable and orderly life 舒适地坐下；平静下来；定居
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He settled down to marking the examination papers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. always moving about, unable to remain still 一直在动的， 停不下来的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The sick child passed a restless night.
